class.name: JointLimitationKusudama3D
class.brief_description: A Kusudama joint limitation that constrains bone orientation using multiple cones connected by tangent paths.
class.description: JointLimitationKusudama3D represents a spherical constraint region using multiple sequence cones that are automatically connected by smooth tangent paths. The term "Kusudama" originates from Japanese papercraft models made by sewing or gluing pyramidal units through a common vertex, which this constraint visually resembles. [b]How Kusudamas Work:[/b] Each cone is defined by a center direction (Vector3) and a radius (half-angle in radians). The constraint allows bone orientations within any of these cones. Additionally, adjacent cones in the sequence are automatically connected by tangent paths, creating a smooth transition region between cones. The inside of tangent circles is forbidden, while the region outside both tangent circles (between the cones) forms the allowed path. [b]Important:[/b] Cones form a linear sequence, not a closed loop. The last cone in the array does not automatically connect back to the first cone. To create a closed constraint region, you must explicitly add a final cone that connects back to the first, or arrange your cones so the last one naturally connects to the first. [b]Constraint Solving Process:[/b] 1. First, the solver checks if the bone direction is within any sequence cone. If so, the orientation is allowed. 2. If not, it checks if the bone direction is within the tangent path regions between adjacent cones. 3. If the bone is outside all allowed regions, it is constrained to the nearest boundary point. [b]Note:[/b] Kusudamas constrain the swing (direction) of the bone. [b]Tangent Cone Calculation:[/b] The tangent cones connecting adjacent sequence cones are automatically calculated. The tangent cone radius is determined by the formula: [code](π - (θa + θb)) / 2[/code], where θa and θb are the apex angles of the two sequence cones being connected. This ensures smooth transitions between cones while maintaining the constraint boundaries.

method.name: get_cone_center
method.description: Returns the center direction vector of the cone at the specified index. This vector points in the direction the cone opens and should be normalized.

method.name: get_cone_count
method.description: Returns the number of cones in this kusudama constraint.

method.name: get_cone_radius
method.description: Returns the radius (half-angle in radians) of the cone at the specified index. This determines how wide the cone opens.

method.name: set_cone_center
method.description: Sets the center direction vector of the cone at the specified index. The vector will be normalized automatically. This defines the direction in which the cone opens.

method.name: set_cone_count
method.description: Sets the number of cones. If increasing the count, new cones are added with default values (center at +Y axis, radius of 0.785398 radians). If decreasing, excess cones are removed.

method.name: set_cone_radius
method.description: Sets the radius (half-angle in radians) of the cone at the specified index. Larger values create wider cones, allowing more freedom in that direction.

members.member: Array of cones defining the allowed swing (directional) regions. Each Vector4 contains (x, y, z, radius) where (x, y, z) is the normalized center direction vector pointing in the direction the cone opens, and radius is the half-angle in radians. Adjacent cones in the array sequence are automatically connected by tangent paths, creating smooth transitions between allowed regions. Note that cones form a linear sequence - the last cone does not automatically connect back to the first cone. The default value represents a single cone opening along the +Y axis with a 45-degree half-angle.

If [code]true[/code], swing (directional) constraints are applied. The bone's direction will be constrained to the union of all cones and their connecting tangent paths. When [code]false[/code], no constraints are applied, allowing free directional movement.
